title: 114_s2750
content: The Act may be cited as the "Charities Helping Americans Regularly Throughout the Year Act". The Senate expresses a sense relating to the protection of charitable deductions. The Senate finds that the deduction for charitable contributions has been important for almost 100 years, encouraging taxpayers to give for the benefit of others. Nonprofit organizations provided 11.4 million jobs in 2012, and charitable giving in 2014 was $358.38 billion, accounting for 2.1% of the GDP. The Senate believes that encouraging charitable giving should be a goal of tax reform. Encouraging charitable giving should be a goal of tax reform, and Congress should ensure that the deduction for charitable contributions is not diminished during a comprehensive rewrite of the tax code. SEC. 3. MODIFICATION OF RULES RELATING TO DONOR ADVISED FUNDS. Modification of rules relating to donor advised funds includes allowing tax-free charitable distributions from individual retirement accounts and return disclosures for distributions made in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2016. The amendment includes new requirements for donor advised funds, such as reporting average contributions and grants over a 3-year period and providing a policy on inactive funds. The organization has no policy regarding the amendments made by this subsection, effective after December 31, 2016. SEC. 4 amends the tax rate for the excise tax on investment income of private foundations from 2 percent to 1 percent and eliminates reduced tax for foundations meeting certain distribution requirements. The changes apply to taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5 mandates electronic filing for annual returns of exempt organizations. SEC. 5 mandates electronic filing for annual returns of exempt organizations, requiring them to file in electronic form and making the returns available to the public in machine-readable format. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. Transitional relief allows small organizations to delay application of the amendments for up to 2 years after the enactment of the Act if it would cause undue burden. The Secretary may delay tax filings for small organizations with gross receipts under $200,000 and gross assets under $500,000. The Secretary may delay the application of the amendments made by this section, but not later than taxable years beginning 2 years after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6 amends the standard mileage rate for charitable contributions deduction, ensuring it is not less than the rate used for medical purposes. The amendment applies to miles traveled after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7 provides an exception from private foundation excess business holding tax for certain philanthropic business holdings. SEC. 7 provides an exception from private foundation excess business holding tax for certain philanthropic business holdings, meeting specific ownership and profit distribution requirements. The private foundation must hold ownership interests in the business enterprise at all times during the taxable year, acquired under a will or trust upon the death of the testator or settlor. The business enterprise must distribute its net operating income to the private foundation within 120 days after the close of the taxable year to meet the all profits to charity requirement. The net operating income of a business enterprise for a taxable year is the gross income reduced by deductions, taxes, and a reserve for working capital. Independent operation requirements are met if maintained throughout the year. The requirements for a private foundation include ensuring that no substantial contributor or their family member is involved in the business enterprise, and the majority of the board of directors are individuals not affiliated with the enterprise. The subsection excludes certain deemed private foundations, such as funds or organizations treated as private foundations by specific sections, and charitable trusts described in section 4947(a)(1). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2016 for charitable trusts described in section 4947(a)(2) (relating to split-interest trusts).
